titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the James Gamble Rogers Papers
titlestmt.author: compiled by John Espy

publicationstmt.publisher: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday April 23, 2019 at 07:11

repository.corpname: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

did.abstract: The papers consist of photographs, plans, drawings, specifications, job files, correspondence, contracts, and printed material, which relate to architectural projects, particularly residences and government, church, hospital, and school buildings, designed by James Gamble Rogers, or the firms of Hale and Rogers, James Gamble Rogers, Inc., and Rogers and Butler. The most extensive files are for buildings on the Yale University campus, but there are also substantial files on the Aetna Life Insurance Company home office, the Columbia-Presbyterian Hospital, the New Haven Post Office and Court House, the Southern Baptist Theological Seminary, and buildings on the campuses of Northwestern University and Columbia University. The papers also include personal papers of James Gamble Rogers and his son Francis Day Rogers.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: James Gamble Rogers Papers (MS 396). Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of the James Gamble Rogers estate, circa. 1960s, and of Pauline Rogers, 1987 and 1994.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 11.75 linear feet (29 boxes)

The James Gamble Rogers Papers came to Yale, probably in the late 1960s, and were first stored in the Plan Room at Buildings and Grounds, 20 Ashmun Street. Some papers were discarded by that office; others, including all plans, sections, and elevations for Yale buildings are still in use there. Some papers, especially detail drawings, were transferred to Manuscripts and Archives, and subsequently all architectural drawings for Yale buildings were placed in the Architectural Archives Collection.

What remains is an uneven and gap-ridden collection of office files; nonetheless it documents phases of the design and planning of much of the Yale campus and half a dozen of Rogers' other projects in New York. The papers are arranged by building or project; they include job files, schedules of hardware, specifications, photographs and drawings, but the files are not complete for any one building.

The job files for the Yale buildings consist largely of correspondence and other papers exchanged with the contractor, Marc Eidlitz & Son of New York City. There is also correspondence with consulting engineer Hollis French, of New Haven and Boston, who drew up many of the specifications.

The photographs are mostly of models for ornamental stonework, sculpted by René P. Chambellan. There are also many photographs of mantels, and photographs of buildings which Rogers hoped to imitate in some feature, and of people whom he planned to represent in the decorations.
More extensive Rogers' correspondence and architectural records can be found in the following collections in Manuscripts and Archives:

list.item: Presidential Records: Arthur T. Hadley --- 2 - A-13
Presidential Records: James R. Angell --- 2 - A-14
Records of the University Librarian --- 32 - C
George Parmly Day Papers --- MS. Grp. No. 174

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: James Gamble Rogers was born on March 3, 1867, in Bryants Station, Kentucky. He received a B.A. degree from Yale University in 1889 and a Diplo?me d'Architecte from the École Nationale et Spéciale des Beaux-Arts in Paris in 1899. He began his architectural practice in New York City in 1905 and was responsible for numerous residences and government, church, hospital, and school buildings. Rogers died on October 1, 1947.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright has been transferred to Yale University for unpublished materials donated by Pauline W. Rogers in Accessions 1988-M-016 and 1995-M-010. Copyright status for the remaining collection materials is unknown. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Received from Pauline Rogers, 1987 Jul 21
Addition inventory by Murat Dogruer and Diane E. Kaplan 1988 April

This addition to the James Gamble Rogers Papers consists of photographs, plans, drawings, financial records, correspondence, and printed material relating to architectural projects designed by James Gamble Rogers or the firms of Hale and Rogers, James Gamble Rogers, Inc., and Rogers and Butler. The most extensive files are for buildings on the Yale University campus, but there are also substantial files on the Aetna Life Insurance Company home office, the Columbia-Presbyterian Hospital, the New Haven Post Office and Court House, the Southern Baptist Theological Seminary, and buildings on the campuses of Northwestern University and Columbia University. The addition also includes some personal papers of James Gamble Rogers and his son, Francis Day Rogers.

The addition is arranged in four sections by record type: Drawings, photographs and construction notes; Published material; Legal and financial records; Personal papers. Papers about a particular project may be found in each section except Personal papers. Photographs and reproductions of plans and drawings comprise the bulk of the addition. The papers include very few original drawings.

The section Drawings, photographs, and construction notes begins with architectural reference files which contain photographs and plans for buildings not designed by James Gamble Rogers or his firms. Rogers collected some of these as a student at the École Nationale et Spéciale des Beaux-Arts in Paris in the 1890s. Others relate to buildings on the Yale campus.

The remainder of the section is composed of drawings, reproductions of drawings, construction notes, construction photographs, and photographs showing completed projects. These materials are arranged alphabetically by project name, with the more voluminous Yale project files preceding the files for all other buildings. Amongst the files for the non-Yale projects are materials relating to church, government, hospital, and school buidings as well as individual residences. Materials in the files are arranged by size, in either flat storage containers for large photographs and drawings or in upright files for notes or other items not larger than 8½" x l5". For any particular building, therefore, there may be two listings in this section, either under the headings "Flat" or "Upright".
Published material is also arranged alphabetically by project name. The files contain articles, clippings, and brochures about building plans, construction, and completed projects.

The Legal and financial records includes numerous contract files containing correspondence, contracts, and some bills and receipts. These files are arranged alphabetically by project name with some general files for "Residences" and "Schools" interspersed. More building projects are documented in this section than in the two preceding sections. The section also includes minutes, payrolls, and other financial records for the firms of Hale and Rogers and James Gamble Rogers, Inc.

Personal papers is composed of correspondence and memorabilia of James Gamble Rogers, as well as some papers of his son, Francis Day Rogers. The latter includes a solicitations notebook for the St. Paul's School Alumni Association and minutes and other records of the Federation of East Lyme Beaches.
